In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the

of any territory or area. 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The  Government  of  Myanmar  has  recently  stepped  up  efforts  to  strengthen  the 
education sector, recognizing an educated population and workforce as essential for sustained 
economic growth and poverty reduction. This is reflected in the government’s critical decision in 
early 2012 to embark on a comprehensive education sector review (CESR)—the first rigorous 
and comprehensive assessment of the education sector in two decades—to provide a basis for 
more clearly identifying sector challenges, priorities, and strategic options. Led by the Ministry of 
Education  (MOE)  coordinating  inputs  by  other  agencies  as  well  as  development  partner 
organizations (DPOs), the CESR will culminate in adoption of a costed education sector plan 
(CESP) document, as a unified framework for prioritized and sequenced investments by the 
government and DPOs.1   
 
2.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has been involved from the earliest stages of 
CESR conceptualization, including participation in a series of forums and working meetings to 
develop a joint plan for the CESR, which was approved by Myanmar’s President on 4 July 2012. 
The government has requested ADB to provide capacity development technical assistance (TA) 
to directly support the CESR, in coordination with support from other DPOs.2 In particular, within 
the CESR, the government and DPOs have called on ADB to support analysis and planning for 
post-primary  education  (PPE)3—as  most  DPOs  will  focus  on  primary,  pre-primary,  and 
nonformal  education—along  with  facilitation  of  access  to  relevant  regional  experience.  In 
addition  to  building  the  analytical  and  planning capacity  of  the  MOE  and  other  agencies4 
through their involvement in CESR analyses, the TA will support applied capacity development 
activities to build the analytical and planning capacities of these agencies. The TA impact, 
outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, cost estimates and financing arrangements, 
and  terms  of  reference  for  initial  consultants  were  agreed  at  TA  fact-finding  during                       
27 August–3 September 2012. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.5 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Important progress has been made in Myanmar’s education sector in recent years, 
perhaps particularly in primary education (grades 1–5) where, despite persistent gaps and 
challenges, the net enrollment ratio reached roughly 90% in school year (SY) 2009/10.6 At the 
same time, progress has lagged in PPE subsectors, with net enrollment ratio estimates for the 
secondary education subsector (SES) ranging from only 53.0% to 58.3%, and much lower for 
technical and vocational education and training (TVET) and the higher education subsector 
(HES).  More  generally,  despite  progress,  the  PPE  subsectors  appear  to  face  particular 
challenges  in  key  aspects  of  equitable  access,  quality  and  relevance,  and  subsector 
                                                
1   The 2-year CESR process will consist of three phases: (i) a roughly 6-month rapid assessment (phase 1), (ii) an 
additional year of in-depth analysis (phase 2), and (iii) a final half year for CESP formulation (phase 3). The CESP 
will include (i) a 2-year plan covering FY2014–FY2015, and (ii) interim planning for education sector investments 
during FY2016–FY2020 and input into formulation of the national multisector Sixth Five-Year Plan. 
2   The Australian Agency for International Development (AusAID) and United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF) are 
leading overall DPO coordination in support of the CESR. 
3   PPE consists of the secondary education subsector (SES), technical and vocational education and training 
(TVET), and the higher education subsector (HES). 
4   The MOE formulates overall education sector policies, while 13 ministries are involved in HES (led by the MOE) 
and 10 in TVET, for which the Ministry of Science and Technology (MOST) is the lead agency, in coordination 
with the MOE.  
5  The concept paper for the TA was approved by the vice-president of Operations 2 on 30 August 2012.  The TA 
first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 28 September 2012.  
6   See also ADB. 2012. Initial Assessment of Post-Primary Education in Myanmar. Manila. This was prepared by 
ADB staff (in dialogue with the MOE, other agencies, and DPOs) to inform ADB support to the joint CESR.

2   
management. Limited available data suggest that gaps in each of these dimensions and their 
impacts  on  PPE  subsector  performance  are  sizeable  (Appendix  2).  Alongside  continued 
progress in primary and pre-primary education, the government has set strengthening of PPE 
as a high priority. As Myanmar embarks on dramatic socioeconomic transformations, PPE must 
play a critical role in (i) promoting inclusive growth and poverty reduction, (ii) meeting rapidly 
evolving labor market needs, and (iii) rebalancing and equipping the economy to modernize and 
move into higher value-added sectors and successfully enter into the Association of Southeast 
Asian Nations (ASEAN) economic community in 2015 and global markets.  
 
4.  At the same time, the dearth of data and information on the education sector (and 
particularly  PPE  subsectors)  poses  a  key  challenge  for  the  MOE  and  other  agencies, 
obstructing concrete diagnoses of key problems and identification of effective interventions. 
Capacities for data analysis and evidence-based sector planning—incorporating international 
experience as well as improved national data—also require strengthening. The CESR will thus 
be  fundamentally  important  as  it  will  more  precisely  pinpoint  sector  (and  PPE  subsector) 
challenges  and  provide  an  evidential  basis  for  identifying  needed  reforms,  defining  clear 
priorities and targets, and developing concrete and sequenced action plans. This process will 
come to fruition with the government’s development of an evidence-based and overarching 
CESP. This will provide a plan for sector improvement and ensure that increased financing 
translates into improved sector performance and contributions to Myanmar’s socioeconomic 
transformation. A number of DPOs have committed to align efforts to support the CESR. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
5.  The TA directly supports the government-led, DPO-supported CESR. Complementing 
support from other DPOs (largely focused on primary, pre-primary, and nonformal education), 
the TA will focus principally on PPE. It will support foundational studies and linked capacity 
development  under  the  CESR’s  phase  1  (rapid  assessment),  and  provide  flexible,  needs-
tailored inputs during phases 2 and 3, leading up to government approval of the CESP.   
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
6.  The impact of the TA will be implementation of viable, sequenced, and adequately 
resourced  education  planning.  Its  outcome  will  be  a  strengthened  knowledge  base  and 
institutional capacity for PPE subsector planning. Integrated within the broader CESR process 
and closely linked to inputs from other DPOs, the TA will help to address key gaps in data and 
information as well as the capacity of the MOE and other agencies for evidence-based planning, 
supporting formulation of the CESP as a unified plan for strengthening the education sector.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
7.  The  TA  will  center  on  three  outputs  related  to  PPE  subsector  studies,  regional 
experience  sharing,  and  strengthening  analytical  and  planning  capacities.  To  ensure 
responsiveness to government needs under the joint CESR and harmonization with support of 
other DPOs (both of which are expected to rapidly evolve), support under each output area will 
be flexible and tailored to needs. While the TA design will specify initial sub-outputs (e.g., 
studies) that directly support the CESR’s initial rapid assessment phase (August 2012–January 
2013), it will allow flexibility to program subsequent sub-outputs on a biannual basis, or as

3 
needed, to ensure rapid response to government priorities as they emerge or are refined later in 
the 2-year CESR process, which will culminate in CESP approval.7    
 
8.  Output 1: Post-primary education subsector studies completed. The TA will support 
studies in identified priority areas under the overall umbrella of the joint CESR. Three initial sub-
outputs will conduct rapid assessments of the SES, TVET, and HES, with the following core 
deliverables feeding directly into a compilation volume of CESR phase 1 studies: (i) a report on 
key challenges facing the SES, as part of a larger cluster study on basic education (grades 1–
11); (ii) a report on labor market dynamics and implications for TVET and the HES; and (iii) a 
report on HES service delivery. Each of these initial sub-outputs will be led by an international 
consultant working closely with CESR Office staff and national consultants being mobilized by 
the  United  Nations  Educational,  Scientific  and  Cultural  Organization  (UNESCO)  and  other 
DPOs. Identification and design of subsequent sub-outputs will be undertaken in late 2012, 
based on emerging findings from CESR phase 1 analysis. In general, studies will (i) include 
disaggregated  analysis,  including  to  the  extent  possible,  gender,  socioeconomic,  and 
geographical  dimensions,  as  well  as  how  these  interact;  (ii)  assess  access,  quality  and 
relevance, and subsector management aspects; and (iii) identify recommendations for policy 
action,  legislation,  program  improvements,  and  institutional  reforms  (including  improved 
coordination mechanisms).8 Development of PPE-related elements of the CESP (during phase 
3 of the CESR) will directly integrate key findings from analysis supported under output 1, as 
well as regional experience and lessons learned under output 2. 
 
9.  Output  2:  Regional  experience  and  lessons  disseminated  and  applied. 
Complementing  analysis  of  Myanmar’s  PPE  subsectors  under  output  1,  the  TA  will  distill 
regional  experience  from  countries  with  similar  contexts,  with  a  focus  on  nearby  ADB 
developing  member  countries  that  have  initiated  systematic  reforms  in  one  or  more  PPE 
subsectors alongside similar socioeconomic transitions.9 While principally focused on PPE, the 
TA will support broader regional sharing of experience on sector-wide and crosscutting issues 
(e.g., developing member country policies on compulsory education and teacher education). 
During CESR phase 1 (rapid assessment), one initial sub-output will prepare and disseminate a 
short, policy-relevant synthesis report on regional experience in the PPE subsectors, drawing on 
various resources including reports and project-related experience from ADB, the Australian 
Agency for  International  Development  (AusAID),  and  other  DPOs.10 A  small  workshop  will 
support  dissemination  and  dialogue  on  implications  for  Myanmar,  and  help  identify  more 
detailed analysis of regional experience and models in priority areas. Subsequent sub-outputs 
supporting CESR phases 2 and 3 will consist principally of desk-research-based comparative 
studies  and  dissemination  workshops  (including  government  agencies,  DPOs,  and  other 
stakeholders),  but may  also  include  limited  support for  other forms  of  regional knowledge 
exchange, such as invitation of regional experts and practitioners to Myanmar.11   
 
10.  Output 3: Analytical and planning capacities of key post-primary education related 
agencies  strengthened.  In  addition  to  ―learning  by  doing‖  under  output  1  and  related 
consultant support, the TA will support focused, needs-tailored capacity development initiatives 
                                                
7   Subsequent sub-outputs and TORs would be reviewed jointly by the MOE, ADB, and AusAID. Similar TA designs 
been very effective in ensuring responsiveness to rapidly evolving needs in several developing member countries.   
8   Phase 1 studies will also inform the analytical agenda for more in-depth PPE-related analyses during phase 2. 
9   Regional experience and lessons shared will include gender-related challenges and responses; and identify 
recommendations for future policy, programs, and capacity development initiatives in Myanmar.  
10  In addition to TA consultant inputs, this sub-output will tap ADB’s PPE subsector experience and AusAID’s 
experience in areas such as primary-to-lower-secondary transitions, TVET, and sister university partnerships.  
11  Opportunities may also be explored to support participation of Myanmar officials in knowledge-exchange events in 
neighboring countries, particularly those in which ADB is supporting similar PPE reforms.

4   
targeted at senior officials and CESR  Office staff from  the MOE, Ministry of Science and 
Technology (MOST), and other agencies involved in PPE.12 Activities will be coordinated with 
support from other DPOs (para. 11) to ensure that support is consistent and complementary. To 
support the post-secondary education (TVET and HES) cluster under CESR phase 1, the initial 
sub-output will support a capacity building seminar to support data collection and analysis for 
staff of the MOE, MOST, and other ministries and institutions.13 A stock-taking exercise late in 
CESR  phase  1  will  identify  priority  capacity  gaps  for  support  under  subsequent  capacity 
development sub-outputs (as well as ongoing consultant support), in order to support PPE-
related analysis and CESP formulation during CESR phases 2 and 3, and looking to CESP 
implementation.  More  focused  activities  will  support  PPE  subsector  decision  makers  in 
responding to specific priority issues. Sub-outputs will integrate gender dimensions, including 
seeking to build capacities of PPE-related agencies in gender-related analysis and planning. 
 
11.  Cross-cutting aspects. All three outputs will involve close coordination and in some 
cases direct collaboration with other DPOs, particularly those involved in the PPE subsectors—
principally  UNESCO  (particularly  for  TVET  and  HES),  GIZ  (for  TVET),  and  the  Japan 
International Cooperation Agency (expected to support CESR work focused on engineering 
fields). A knowledge plan (to be jointly formulated early in the TA and updated periodically) will 
provide an overall framework for report dissemination, knowledge sharing workshops, and other 
interventions. In addition to more detailed study reports under outputs 1 and 2, deliverables for 
each sub-output will include a synopsis monograph. Focused synopses, to be disseminated in 
English  and  Myanmar  languages,  will  be  self-contained  and  provide  a  selective  summary 
focusing on distilling the key policy-relevant issues and recommendations.14  
 
12.   The risk of a reversal in Myanmar’s political and socioeconomic policy reforms appears 
small (with recent parliamentary elections pointing to growing momentum), as does risk of a 
deprioritization of education sector development and the CESR, which is fully government-
owned and supported from the highest levels (para. 2). Multi-stakeholder coordination and 
institutional capacities among the multiple ministries involved may pose challenges. However, 
the education sector has thus far stood out as a leading example of coordination, while the 
CESR’s phased approach, mechanisms for multi-stakeholder engagement,15 and DPO support 
for capacity development will help support effective implementation.16   
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $720,000 equivalent, of which (i) $200,000 will be financed 
on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources); and (ii) 
$370,000 equivalent will be financed on a grant basis by the Government of Australia and 
administered by ADB.17 The Government of Myanmar will provide counterpart support in the 
form of counterpart staff, office accommodation and supplies, meeting venues, administrative 
support, and other in-kind contributions. The TA will finance (i) expert inputs (para. 15); (ii)

management support to the MOE and the CESR Office, as well as training, other capacity building, and other 
support for the CESR, with an overall focus on primary, pre-primary, and nonformal education.    
13   Supported by the TA consultants, the seminar will be conducted jointly with UNESCO and Deutsche Gesellschaft 
für Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ), with participation by other DPOs interested in specific focal areas. 
14  These  include  identification  of  gaps  and  recommendations  related  to  policy  and  legislation,  operational 
 
mechanisms, and/or implementation capacities.    
15  These include the joint education sector working group consisting of government agencies and DPOs. 
16  Any minor equipment is expected to be procured by ADB-recruited consultants. ADB staff will provide the MOE 
and other participating agencies with further orientation regarding various aspects of TA administration.

workshops and knowledge-exchange activities, including costs related to resource persons, 
venue, equipment rental, translation, printing and copying, food and nonalcoholic beverages, 
transportation and lodging, logistics, and administration support; (iii) resource materials and 
minor computer equipment, and other costs related to surveys, field investigations, and data 
entry; and (iv) other allowable expenditures as agreed by ADB.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  The MOE will be the executing agency. The TA will be implemented from October 2012 
to October 2014.18 To support harmonization and coordination across elements of the CESR 
and DPO support, the CESR Office will act as implementing agency for the TA, supporting day-
to-day implementation and coordination across related agencies and DPOs.19 The government 
established the CESR Office to coordinate the overall CESR process. Full-time staff seconded 
from the MOE and other agencies20 are supported by two long-term international advisors and 
other shorter-term consultants funded by other DPOs.   
 
15.  The TA will support indicatively 18.0 person-months of international consultants and 18.0 
person-months of national consultants, who will have expertise in the SES, TVET, and/or HES 
and will be recruited as individuals and engaged by ADB in accordance with the Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Terms of reference and key 
deliverables for three consultants supporting phase 1 sub-outputs are in Appendix 4.21 The TA 
will also flexibly mobilize short-term resource persons to provide specific expertise, as needed. 
While not reflected in the cost estimates, ADB and AusAID staff with expertise in the SES, 
TVET, and HES will be directly involved in TA implementation, including in identifying new sub-
outputs and reviewing draft reports, as well as development (early in the TA) of the noted 
knowledge  plan (para. 11).22 Support  under the TA  will  be  linked  with  inputs  provided  by 
UNESCO  (particularly  for  TVET  and  HES),  GIZ  (for  TVET),  and  the  Japan  International 
Cooperation Agency (expected to support CESR work focused on engineering fields). More 
broadly, continuous dialogue will be maintained with national and DPO stakeholders through the 
CESR Office, joint education sector working group, and other coordination mechanisms.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $370,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Government of Australia, and (ii) ADB providing the balance 
not exceeding the equivalent of $200,000 on a grant basis, to the Government of Myanmar for 
Support for Education Sector Planning, and hereby reports this action to the Board.  
                                                
18  Within the MOE, the Department of Education Planning and Training acts as the focal point of the CESR as well 
as for broader coordination across ministries and departments and cooperation with DPOs. 
19  A CESR steering committee will support higher-level policy dialogue and coordination related to the CESR. 
20  These include four full-time staff from the MOE and MOST to support HES and TVET studies (two each), while 
other CESR Office staff will partially focus on the SES under the broader basic education (grades 1–11) cluster.    
21  Three international consultants will have a total input of 8.0 person-months. Pending review, consultants will 
administer  TA-funded  procurements  and  workshop  expenses.  In  all  cases,  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time), Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from 
time to time), and other ADB guidelines shall be applied. Equipment (indicatively two laptop computers and one 
digital camera) will be turned over to MOE after TA completion. 
22  ADB staff involvement is strongly justified given the importance of continued relationship-building with government 
agencies and DPOs involved in the education sector, and as part of ADB’s broader reengagement in Myanmar.

8  Appendix 2 
SUMMARY OVERVIEW OF KEY ISSUES FACING POST-PRIMARY EDUCATION ACCESS, 
QUALITY, AND MANAGEMENT 
 
1.  This appendix provides a summary of key challenges facing post-primary education 
(PPE) in Myanmar, distilling findings from an initial analysis of available data and information 
conducted by Asian Development Bank (ADB) staff—in dialogue with the Ministry of Education 
(MOE), other agencies, and development partner organizations (DPOs)—to inform ADB support 
to the joint comprehensive education sector review (CESR). That initial analysis pointed to 
important  achievements  made  in  the  secondary  education  subsector  (SES),  technical  and 
vocational education and training (TVET) and the higher education subsector (HES). However, 
for brevity, the summary below focuses on key challenges in these PPE subsectors. 
 
2.  Gaps in access. While total enrollments in middle school (grades 6–9) and high school 
(grades  10–11)  grew  at  annual  rates  of  3.6%  and  1.6%  respectively  during  SY2000/01–
SY2007/08,  they  subsequently  decelerated,  with  a  sizeable  decline  in  total  high  school 
enrollment  during  SY2007/08–SY2010/11.  Household  surveys  suggest  that  nearly  half  of 
secondary school-aged children are out of school. Exit from school is particularly marked at the 
transition from primary to middle school: cohort-based analysis suggest that one in four primary 
school  completers  never  enter  middle  school,  despite  some  signs  of  progress.  Moreover, 
aggregate figures conceal sizeable geographic and socioeconomic gaps, and such disparities 
appear much larger in SES than at the primary level.1 While aggregate figures show strong 
gender parity overall, girls in poor families, remote rural areas, and some ethnic groups may be 
particularly disadvantaged, i.e., the influences of gender and other socioeconomic dimensions 
are interlinked.2 Expansion of ―post-primary schools‖ (adding early middle school grades at 
existing primary school sites) has helped expand access, but key issues remain, particularly in 
poor  and  ethnic  areas.  These  include  (i)  disparities  in  completion  rates  and  levels  of 
preparedness from the primary level; (ii) demand-side factors such as financial and opportunity 
costs, language and other cultural factors, and disabilities; and (iii) supply-side factors such as 
gaps in school networks in remote areas, financial and human resources, and quality.  
 
3.  Data is more limited for TVET and HES, but points to rising numbers of institutions and 
students.3 Females  constitute  at  least  60%  of  HES  enrollments,  but  appear  to  be  under 
represented in TVET.4 At the same time, while data is limited, there likely remain sizeable 
disparities in access to TVET and HES by socioeconomic and ethnic groups, including due to 
direct and indirect costs. For TVET (which also includes a smaller number of programs at the 
secondary level), a key priority appears to be expanding access to relevant quality skills training 
and upgrading opportunities for workers and unemployed and underemployed youth (including 
school leavers) and adults from poorer rural areas.5 For HES, another major issue is the inability 
                                                
1 Based on household surveys cited in the noted initial assessment, 52.4% of 10- to 15-year-olds from households in 
the poorest wealth quintile are already out-of-school (versus only 9.5% for the richest quintile). 
2 An estimated 55.8% of 10- to 15-year-old girls in the poorest quintile of households are out-of-school (versus 48.8% 
for boys), with similar figures for girls and boys in Rakhine state. Mothers’ education appears especially important 
for girls’ schooling. 
3 HES has expanded dramatically, from 32 institutions and 131,837 undergraduate and higher-level students in 
SY1997/98 to 163 institutions (under 13 ministries) and 510,891 students in SY2011/12.   
4 Ten ministries offer TVET programs, with the Ministry of Science and Technology (MOST) as overall lead. The gap 
in labor force participation between females (63%) and males (85%) also in part likely reflects issues related to 
access to high quality and relevant skill training, as well as issues related to gender norms within and beyond PPE.  
5 TVET expansion and system strengthening appears a high priority for promoting fully inclusive growth. The vast 
majority of the labor force requires improved skills to increase productivity: a difficult task given that more than 90% 
of workers nationwide appear to be engaged in agriculture and/or working in the informal sector or self-employed.

Appendix 2  9 
of two-thirds of high school completers to pass the matriculation exam (para. 4), which also pre-
selects passers into fields of study. 
 
4.  Gaps in quality and relevance. There is a particular lack of systematic data relating to 
PPE quality and relevance, but anecdotal evidence suggests challenges in terms of teaching 
(still  largely  rote-based)  and  learning  outcomes.  Available  SES  data  suggest  that  grade 
repetition is rather modest, but rises in the final year of middle school (grade 9), becoming 
especially problematic in high school (grades 10–11). Combined with high matriculation exam 
failure rates, this suggests problems in students’ mastery of subject content.6 Priorities identified 
for the CESR include (i) a systematic review of detailed curricula and teaching materials used in 
SES, approaches to student assessment, and the use of English for teaching high school math 
and sciences; (ii) strengthening of SES teacher training and support, to encourage a shift from 
rote-based to student-centered learning, as well as teacher deployment and broader human 
resource  issues;  (iii)  investment  in  facilities  and  materials  for  teaching  and  learning;  and           
(iv) efforts to address equity and quality concerns arising from private tuition (e.g., for-fee 
tutoring).  
 
6.  To  ensure  that  TVET  and  HES  effectively  support  Myanmar’s  socioeconomic 
transformation, both subsectors will need to introduce more fully competency-based curricula 
and address gaps in (i) relevance of curricula and materials, methodology, and overall program 
design to shifting demands, and alignment across TVET, HES, and SES; (ii) quality control and 
accreditation, particularly given a proliferation of institutions and programs of varying quality;           
(iii) faculty qualifications and professional support systems; and (iv) links to labor market needs, 
especially in emerging sectors and skill areas. For TVET, the CESR will be critical in providing 
the first in-depth review of the subsector, with priorities including (i) streamlining TVET and 
enhancing quality and relevance; (ii) developing an updated policy framework for TVET and 
occupational competency standards and qualification frameworks; and (iii) bolstering related 
capacities  of  the  National  Skills  Standard  Authority  and  other  institutions.  HES-specific 
challenges  include  the  need  to  (i)  overhaul  the  matriculation  exam  and  HES  student 
assessment; (ii) review the use of English to teach math and sciences; (iii) enhance applied 
research capacity; and (iv) expand international linkages. 
 
6.  Gaps in subsector management. Inadequate financing remains an overarching issue 
for the education sector. The new government’s redoubled focus on education appears to be 
translating into increased resourcing: the FY2012 budget for education more than doubled in 
nominal terms, with the share of an increasing total national budget allocated to education rising 
from 3.74% to 6.26%, though this remains very low by international standards.7 While DPO 
support  will  likely  increase,  continued  increases  in  (and  careful  prioritization  and  effective 
management of) state financing for education will be critical. Detailed analysis under the CESR 
is needed to pinpoint and address other key gaps in sector management that interlink with 
access and quality issues, undermining education sector performance. Many of these appear 
most pronounced in PPE, including gaps related to (i) coordination across multiple ministries 
and MOE departments; (ii) data and information to inform policy, planning, and budgeting;       
(iii) overall institutional capacity; (iv) human resources and technical and managerial capacities; 
(v) systems for assessing teachers and faculty and learning outcomes, as well as broader 
quality control; and (vi) new frameworks for private TVET and HES institutions.8   
                                                
6 Taken at the end of grade 11, this exam is currently the basis for both certification of high school completion and 
selection into HES programs. In SY2009/10, 61.3% of test takers failed, undermining the benefits of high school.     
7 The share of the education budget in GDP is expected to double from 0.69% to a projected value of 1.4%–1.5%. 
8 Starting in SY2012/13, MOE plans to allow registration of private schools, but only for grades 1–11.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will mobilize international and national experts to support 
analyses, workshops, and other agreed sub-output activities under the umbrella of Myanmar’s 
comprehensive  education  sector  review  (CESR),  including  by  providing  international  best 
practice, in-depth local knowledge, support for capacity development initiatives, and/or policy-
related advice to the CESR. Expert inputs will consist of (i) individual consultants, to be recruited 
by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in dialogue with the Ministry of Education (MOE) and 
other  agencies  involved  in  post-primary  education  (PPE) 1  work  under  the  CESR;  and                
(ii) resource persons needed to provide focused, short-term inputs (up to 10 working days 
maximum).  Expert  inputs  will  be  coordinated  with  the  CESR  Office—set  up  to  support 
coordination across all aspects of the CESR, which will include support from many development 
partner organizations (DPOs)—and harmonized with inputs from other DPOs. To ensure timely 
and effective response to evolving government needs and DPO support linked to the CESR, the 
flexible design of the TA specifies five initial sub-outputs (e.g., studies) that directly support the 
CESR’s initial rapid assessment phase (August 2012–January 2013), allowing subsequent sub-
outputs to be added during phases 2 and 3 of the 2-year CESR process.   
 
2.  This  document  provides  outline  terms  of  reference  for  three  initial  international 
consultants2 (totaling 8.0 person-months, on an intermittent basis) whose inputs will focus on 
supporting rapid assessment work3 on the PPE subsectors under CESR phase 1.4 It also 
provides a general framework for mobilization of other experts during TA implementation, with 
specific terms of reference for new sub-outputs to be agreed jointly with the MOE (as TA 
executing  agency)  and  the  Australian  Agency  for  International  Development  (AusAID).  As 
applicable, such dialogue will also include the Ministry of Science and Technology (MOST) 
and/or other agencies and institutions, as needed (particularly for TVET and the HES). Inclusive 
of  the  initial  consultants,  it  is  expected  that  the  TA  will  finance  18.0  person-months  of 
international  consultant  inputs,  18.0  person-months  of  national  consultant  inputs,  and  200 
working days of resource person inputs.5 
 
3.  Within 2 weeks of fielding, consultants will propose a detailed work plan, based on 
discussion with the CESR Office and CESR teams working on various cluster studies to ensure 
coordination and a clear division of labor. Additionally, early in the TA, ADB, AusAID, the MOE, 
and other relevant agencies will develop a knowledge plan (to be updated periodically, as 
needed) to provide an overall framework for reports, workshops, and other knowledge sharing 
and dissemination interventions under various sub-outputs. In general, for each sub-output, a 
designated international consultant will take lead responsibility for drafting either or both of the 
following written deliverables:6 (i) for analytical work under outputs 1 and 2, a sub-output final
